Pop culture has turned us into a generation that believes men just want to watch Football on Sundays and occasionally get dragged to church by their wives; but look at the successful churches, look at Islam as it spreads over the globe, look at Jews as their faith community becomes powerful...noticed anything about them? 

That's right - it's your job as a man to keep the faith, not only for yourself, but for your family.

@gaycuttlefish @yifton @caution I've gotten way better at finding content to post, but here's the problem: I *still* can't think of any titles.

For example, one of the most recent posts was "fluffy roll". It made sense, and honestly made the whole post 10x better. But I haven't been able to do that, scrolling through every one of these images the only titles I can come up is describing exactly what I see: https://twitter.com/hourlyFox

So how are you doing it? I could sit there for an hour and never figure out anything, while most of you just think of something super creative no sweat. What's going on here?

Just so you know, I'm a much more experienced person asking for advice from people doing this as beginners, and probably not even intentionally. This is pretty much my life for ya.

body:
>  I decided to go look at the ruqqus source code and search for anything related to ruqqus premium to see if I could find any bugs or whatnot. So I tried to see if there were any issues with tipping, and I found out that it checks to see if you're tipping 0 coins or if you don't have enough coins, but not if you're tipping a negative amount of coins. So I tried it, was able to get 999 coins, and decided to tell captainmeta4.

Yeah, I could NEVER EVER EVER EVER EVER EVER EVER find anything wrong just by looking at the source code, no matter how hard I look, especially not something like that! I'm a total complete piece of SHIT!!!!!

https://i.ibb.co/zFXYPYg/ruqquscreature2.png

Oh, you can draw pretty well too. That drawing is almost perfect, all the lines and shading and shapes line up absolutely PERFECTLY! I can't even do shading or perspectives in the first place, and all my lines and shapes are sloppy and messy and don't match perfectly and the lines aren't perfectly aligned, because it's almost impossible to do that, but you did it effortlessly. And I've been doing quite a lot of it for several years, yet you just decided to make this today and I could NEVER EVER EVER EVER EVER do that!

After someone [tipped me some coins](https://ruqqus.com/+GoForCoins/post/5bkz/ruqqus-mascot-redesign-competition/igjp), I decided to go look at the ruqqus source code and search for anything related to ruqqus premium to see if I could find any bugs or whatnot. So I tried it, was able to get 999 coins, and decided to tell captainmeta4.

I guess it's a combination of being bored and trying to look for stuff intentionally (sometimes, I have something in mind that I want to look for, and most of the time I look, I also don't find anything).

body:
Practice clearly isn't the reason when I have been confirmed to be practicing way more than him in at least programming and he probably barely does vector art either. He is not even a programmer, and I am, yet he's the one that knows everything and can see bugs just by skimming through code. So in at least one case, and very likely both, I have practiced way more than him.

> Also, sfrohne's submission isn't "subpixel perfect" nor "symmetrical", I could spot asymmetry & misalignment in less than 15 seconds. His work is not perfect, but it's definitely good enough.

Well compared to mine it is. Here's the best I could possibly do with it (and keep in mind it's after I already knew how he did it):

![](https://i.imgur.com/iq94Xck.png)

Note that I have had several years of practice trying to do this, and I still absolutely fucking suck at it. But I've never heard of @sfrohne doing it before, it sounds like he only did it because he wanted to make a joke submission to the mascot contest. And he also depicted it in a very clever manner that makes it look better, so if I did that part too my version would be even worse. Not that I could have that full of an idea and concept in the first place, let alone so quickly for a joke. I could probably spend days of serious thinking on it and still only think of the existing ruqqus mascot, whereas he quickly imagined a creature with distinct features, and ones that fit and make a lot of sense too, not just random.

And yeah, my clone of his image isn't that bad, but his is mostly professional looking and everything lines up and fits together. You can easily tell mine is messy and amateur, especially if you zoom in and look at the shapes and lines and shading and stuff (the little details), whereas his does not have these problems. I could spend hours or days on it and not improve it hardly at all. Yet he can just pick it up, make something as a joke, and have it near-perfect. On top of that, I'm much worse at shading, to the point where I usually just don't bother with it, but he seems to already be able to do it properly without too much thought. I'm a little better on perspective but his is still better (mostly evident by the crown) and his objects are aligned much better than mine, almost perfectly, unlike mine which are more like chicken scratch and I have no idea how to fix it up right.

Acikek is similar to sfrohne and is also much younger than I am, yet also does everything consistently and solidly, and seems to magically know everything despite less experience.

body:
> My submission wasn't meant to be a joke submission. I was asking if joke submissions were okay since I saw others making them (the purple snoo and the one by milkit).
> 
> I've been drawing for over 8 years, which means I do have some experience/practice

Okay that makes more sense. You're really similar to me and most people on ruqqus are about my age (including the other "savants") so I assumed this was just another case of that.

> There's some misalignment at the bottom, and I also wasn't sure how to get it to be symmetric (I drew the left side first, and I copied and pasted it to make the right side, but I had trouble connecting the two sides together), so it ended up having some asymmetry.

True although the different color shades line up pretty much exactly. Don't know which program you're using but for me all the different colors have to be separate objects, thus they are prone to not aligning with the parent exactly (example: the shading spots under the head and ears). My actual *drawings* aren't bad (aside from the shading, will need some advice on that) but the messiness of my vector components is awful. For example I can drag two curves to be *roughly* the same but not quite, and they're an imperfect shape compared to optimally. Or I can't align different objects exactly, etc. Everything's always just a little off, which would be fine for on paper but vector graphics are meant to be more precise looking and I've never been able to figure out how to do that. And it's also not exactly consistent (ex the tops of the crown are irregularly shaped triangles and also not exactly the same as each other). It makes it look sloppy and amateur, whereas yours is (mostly) exact and would pass as a legit corporate logo.

> I usually try to think of things like unconventional inputs or cases that the devs may have forgotten about.

Me too but they always go over my head. The thing that separates us the most is that you seem to have a *ton* of knowledge about every function and library, so mistakes stick out like an eyesore to you. But for us mortals, it's a lot harder to see. I admit the negative coins thing wasn't that difficult to catch, but the color codes one 99.9% of people wouldn't have noticed since it goes through your head that it's 1-2, 3-4, 5-6 and that looks right. Unless you're writing it, the exclusivity of the end of the range isn't something you tend to notice. They're hard to notice exactly because they're unconventional, and you don't think of them.

> I'm sort of wondering what you thought the features meant (if you can find meaning from them, that would be pretty cool).

I just thought they all fit really well, that's all.

> I actually think your depiction is pretty good (in my opinion, at least)

It's hard to say what it is specifically but yours definitely has charm to it and mine looks more just thrown together. That is a very crucial missing element in my opinion, and it's very hard to determine exactly what it is. You can just kinda tell by looking at it. Yours flows way better.

I'd also mention that yours definitely looks 3-dimensional while mine is more flat looking, especially the head and body and bottom tentacles. I know the right arm has awkward shading but even the other parts still look more like a paper cutout rather than an object.

> I think that some changes I would make is that I'd make the mouth and the bottom of the crown a bit rounder

Another misalignment issue I struggle with, since I have to guess with the bezier path tools.

>  I also think that the shading on the left is a bit awkward (it makes the arm seem flat, and the bottom is not connected to the edge of the body), but since I'm not that knowledgeable about shading, I don't really know how to fix it.

Yeah I mentioned I can't do shading hardly at all. I can wing it but the result is usually awkward. I know yours isn't technically correct but it looks nice.

> and I tried to think of what it should have on each part of the body (What should it have on the head? Should it have arms or wings or anything like that?

Yeah that's the biggest part I struggle with. I can think of random things but they are all awkward. Yours fit the creature really nice. Perhaps that's just luck this time, idk, but it's my first impression so that's what I see.

> But then I realize that their abilities probably came from a lot of practice and a lot of time spent on learning about the thing they're good at.

Most times when I notice it's with something I've also had a lot of time and practice with.

> You can also try looking up resources on specific things like shading/perspective.

My problem is, like in programming, even after learning the basics of something (say shading) I still lack the intuition to really nail it. I improve but I still have to make a lot of guesses. Also there's not too many resources on some of my weak spots, for example spotting code bugs, finding hidden away documentation or tools that are well known but not really announced anywhere, image charm, and roughness/inaccuracies and messiness for vector images.
body_html:
My submission wasn't meant to be a joke submission. I was asking if joke submissions were okay since I saw others making them (the purple snoo and the one by milkit).

I've been drawing for over 8 years, which means I do have some experience/practice

Okay that makes more sense. You're really similar to me and most people on ruqqus are about my age (including the other "savants") so I assumed this was just another case of that.

There's some misalignment at the bottom, and I also wasn't sure how to get it to be symmetric (I drew the left side first, and I copied and pasted it to make the right side, but I had trouble connecting the two sides together), so it ended up having some asymmetry.

True although the different color shades line up pretty much exactly. Don't know which program you're using but for me all the different colors have to be separate objects, thus they are prone to not aligning with the parent exactly (example: the shading spots under the head and ears). My actual drawings aren't bad (aside from the shading, will need some advice on that) but the messiness of my vector components is awful. For example I can drag two curves to be roughly the same but not quite, and they're an imperfect shape compared to optimally. Or I can't align different objects exactly, etc. Everything's always just a little off, which would be fine for on paper but vector graphics are meant to be more precise looking and I've never been able to figure out how to do that. And it's also not exactly consistent (ex the tops of the crown are irregularly shaped triangles and also not exactly the same as each other). It makes it look sloppy and amateur, whereas yours is (mostly) exact and would pass as a legit corporate logo.

I usually try to think of things like unconventional inputs or cases that the devs may have forgotten about.

Me too but they always go over my head. The thing that separates us the most is that you seem to have a ton of knowledge about every function and library, so mistakes stick out like an eyesore to you. But for us mortals, it's a lot harder to see. I admit the negative coins thing wasn't that difficult to catch, but the color codes one 99.9% of people wouldn't have noticed since it goes through your head that it's 1-2, 3-4, 5-6 and that looks right. Unless you're writing it, the exclusivity of the end of the range isn't something you tend to notice. They're hard to notice exactly because they're unconventional, and you don't think of them.

I'm sort of wondering what you thought the features meant (if you can find meaning from them, that would be pretty cool).

I just thought they all fit really well, that's all.

I actually think your depiction is pretty good (in my opinion, at least)

It's hard to say what it is specifically but yours definitely has charm to it and mine looks more just thrown together. That is a very crucial missing element in my opinion, and it's very hard to determine exactly what it is. You can just kinda tell by looking at it. Yours flows way better.

I'd also mention that yours definitely looks 3-dimensional while mine is more flat looking, especially the head and body and bottom tentacles. I know the right arm has awkward shading but even the other parts still look more like a paper cutout rather than an object.

I think that some changes I would make is that I'd make the mouth and the bottom of the crown a bit rounder

Another misalignment issue I struggle with, since I have to guess with the bezier path tools.

I also think that the shading on the left is a bit awkward (it makes the arm seem flat, and the bottom is not connected to the edge of the body), but since I'm not that knowledgeable about shading, I don't really know how to fix it.

Yeah I mentioned I can't do shading hardly at all. I can wing it but the result is usually awkward. I know yours isn't technically correct but it looks nice.

and I tried to think of what it should have on each part of the body (What should it have on the head? Should it have arms or wings or anything like that?

Yeah that's the biggest part I struggle with. I can think of random things but they are all awkward. Yours fit the creature really nice. Perhaps that's just luck this time, idk, but it's my first impression so that's what I see.

But then I realize that their abilities probably came from a lot of practice and a lot of time spent on learning about the thing they're good at.

Most times when I notice it's with something I've also had a lot of time and practice with.

You can also try looking up resources on specific things like shading/perspective.

My problem is, like in programming, even after learning the basics of something (say shading) I still lack the intuition to really nail it. I improve but I still have to make a lot of guesses. Also there's not too many resources on some of my weak spots, for example spotting code bugs, finding hidden away documentation or tools that are well known but not really announced anywhere, image charm, and roughness/inaccuracies and messiness for vector images.

guild.description:
A uuid is unique, it is one of a kind, it is ephemeral. A uuid is generated for a purpose and then tossed aside, never to be seen or used again.

Generate and post a uuid to give it a meaning a little longer than most. Each post should serve to honor the beauty of a single uuid. Maybe your uuid has certain properties that make it special. Maybe there is a sequence or palindrome in a substring of that uuid.

Let's talk about them.

parent.body:
I wanted to clear a few things up.

1. My submission wasn't meant to be a joke submission. I was asking if joke submissions were okay since I saw others making them (the purple snoo and the one by milkit).
2. I've been drawing for over 8 years, which means I do have some experience/practice. (I've never taken classes on digital art though, and I don't know that much about perspective/shading since I just draw for fun). I just don't really post any of my drawings online. (You definitely have a lot more experience in programming though.)
3. Like Seq37 said, my drawing isn't exactly perfect. There's some misalignment at the bottom, and I also wasn't sure how to get it to be symmetric (I drew the left side first, and I copied and pasted it to make the right side, but I had trouble connecting the two sides together), so it ended up having some asymmetry.
4. I don't really just "skim over" the code and see bugs every time. Like Seq37 said, I think I also try to look at individual lines and try to think of ways to "abuse" them. I usually try to think of things like unconventional inputs or cases that the devs may have forgotten about.
5. (Also, the least important thing: I'm actually a girl, but that probably doesn't matter)

>very clever manner

What do you mean?

>he quickly imagined a creature with distinct features, and ones that fit and make a lot of sense too, not just random

The tentacles and arms were completely random. The ears were kind of based on elf ears, but that's it. I'm sort of wondering what you thought the features meant (if you can find meaning from them, that would be pretty cool).

What I did here was that I tried to think of the general shape of the creature (is it humanoid, is it a blob, is it an object, is it something else?), and I tried to think of what it should have on each part of the body (What should it have on the head? Should it have arms or wings or anything like that? Are there any features that would make it feel medieval?) However, if you'd like advice on coming up with ideas, I'm probably not the best person to ask since I usually have trouble with it (I tried to think of a flag for ruqqus a while back and still haven't come up with anything).

I actually think your depiction is pretty good (in my opinion, at least). I think that some changes I would make is that I'd make the mouth and the bottom of the crown a bit rounder (I drew the crown on mine using triangles and an oval), and I'd make the arms a bit less thin. I also think that the shading on the left is a bit awkward (it makes the arm seem flat, and the bottom is not connected to the edge of the body), but since I'm not that knowledgeable about shading, I don't really know how to fix it. (If I were to do it, I'd probably end up making the entire left side of the body darker, assuming the light is coming from the top right.)

>Acikek is similar to sfrohne and is also much younger than I am, yet also does everything consistently and solidly

I usually feel this way too when seeing someone who's younger and lot more talented than I am. But then I realize that their abilities probably came from a lot of practice and a lot of time spent on learning about the thing they're good at.

I don't think that it's too good to self-deprecate like this. I think that if you want to improve on drawing, for example, you can try showing one of your drawings to someone who's better at it and ask for advice. You can also try looking up resources on specific things like shading/perspective.

The reason it's so high is because they tend to count everything they possibly can as a death for covid. So for example if you're in a car crash and test positive they count that as a covid death. The reason is because they get rewarded for doing so, because there is much money and power to be made off of a fake crisis.

Also not every strand of flu is the same. Some are more mild like a common cold and others hit you pretty hard.
